subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Parralel Systems
msgSnippet: ... Well, I will be happy if at first we can get this 2.0 working well on the computer.  But one thing that does actually bother me is the vertical height
messageBody:
On 19 Jul 2006, at 21:43, tim_rice09 wrote:
> I think that Quickscript is
> version 2.0 of the Shaw alphabets. What are some things to improve
> in version 3?

Well, I will be happy if at first we can get this 2.0 working well on
the computer. But one thing that does actually bother me is the
vertical height required for Quickscript. The tall/short/deep
portions of the characters are all supposed to be roughly the same
size (according to the manual), so the line height is generally
greater than for TO... this ends up erasing the purported benefits of
space savings. The Jerome font did away with this convention without
sacrificing the distinction between characters, so it would be nice
if the convention were to keep the tall and deep sections
proportionally smaller than the short section.

(The Jerome font, however, has added some serifs and changed glyph
shapes in a way that I find confusing: I can't read it as easily as
Jeremy or Kingsley.)

oliver

> version 2.0 of the Shaw alphabets. What are some things to improve
> in version 3?

Well, I will be happy if at first we can get this 2.0 working well on

vertical height required for Quickscript.  The tall/short/deep  
portions of the characters are all supposed to be roughly the same  
size (according to the manual), so the line height is generally  
greater than for TO... this ends up erasing the purported benefits of  
space savings.  The Jerome font did away with this convention without  
sacrificing the distinction between characters, so it would be nice  
if the convention were to keep the tall and deep sections  
proportionally smaller than the short section.

(The Jerome font, however, has added some serifs and changed glyph  
shapes in a way that I find confusing: I can't read it as easily as  
Jeremy or Kingsley.)
